info.title: Medical Entity API
info.description: The most generic type of entity related to health and the practice of medicine.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Keyword search for item

parameters.name: additionaltype
parameters.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

parameters.name: adverseoutcome
parameters.description: A possible complication and/or side effect of this therapy. If it is known that an adverse outcome is serious (resulting in death, disability, or permanent damage; requiring hospitalization; or is otherwise life-threatening or requires immediate medical attention), tag it as a seriouseAdverseOutcome instead.

parameters.name: alternatename
parameters.description: An alias for the item.

parameters.name: causeof
parameters.description: The condition, complication, symptom, sign, etc. caused.

parameters.name: code
parameters.description: A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A short description of the item.

parameters.name: estimatesriskof
parameters.description: The condition, complication, or symptom whose risk is being estimated.

parameters.name: guideline
parameters.description: A medical guideline related to this entity.

parameters.name: guidelinesubject
parameters.description: The medical conditions, treatments, etc. that are the subject of the guideline.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

parameters.name: increasesriskof
parameters.description: The condition, complication, etc. influenced by this factor.

parameters.name: mainentityofpage
parameters.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.

parameters.name: medicinesystem
parameters.description: The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the item.

parameters.name: potentialaction
parameters.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

parameters.name: recognizingauthority
parameters.description: If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.

parameters.name: relevantspecialty
parameters.description: If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.

parameters.name: sameas
parameters.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

parameters.name: seriousadverseoutcome
parameters.description: A possible serious complication and/or serious side effect of this therapy. Serious adverse outcomes include those that are life-threatening; result in death, disability, or permanent damage; require hospitalization or prolong existing hospitalization; cause congenital anomalies or birth defects; or jeopardize the patient and may require medical or surgical intervention to prevent one of the outcomes in this definition.

parameters.name: study
parameters.description: A medical study or trial related to this entity.

parameters.name: studysubject
parameters.description: A subject of the study, i.e. one of the medical conditions, therapies, devices, drugs, etc. investigated by the study.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: URL of the item.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

description.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
The anatomy of the underlying organ system or structures associated with this entity.
An underlying cause. More specifically, one of the causative agent(s) that are most directly responsible for the pathophysiologic process that eventually results in the occurrence.
A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.
A short description of the item.
One or more alternative conditions considered in the differential diagnosis process.

One of a set of differential diagnoses for the condition. Specifically, a closely-related or competing diagnosis typically considered later in the cognitive process whereby this medical condition is distinguished from others most likely responsible for a similar collection of signs and symptoms to reach the most parsimonious diagnosis or diagnoses in a patient.
The characteristics of associated patients, such as age, gender, race etc.
The likely outcome in either the short term or long term of the medical condition.
A medical guideline related to this entity.
Expectations for health conditions of target audience.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.
The name of the item.
The expected progression of the condition if it is not treated and allowed to progress naturally.
Changes in the normal mechanical, physical, and biochemical functions that are associated with this activity or condition.

A possible unexpected and unfavorable evolution of a medical condition. Complications may include worsening of the signs or symptoms of the disease, extension of the condition to other organ systems, etc.
A possible treatment to address this condition, sign or symptom.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
A preventative therapy used to prevent an initial occurrence of the medical condition, such as vaccination.
If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.
A medical condition associated with this anatomy.
If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.
A modifiable or non-modifiable factor that increases the risk of a patient contracting this condition, e.g. age,  coexisting condition.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A preventative therapy used to prevent reoccurrence of the medical condition after an initial episode of the condition.
A sign or symptom of this condition. Signs are objective or physically observable manifestations of the medical condition while symptoms are the subjective experience of the medical condition.
The stage of the condition, if applicable.
A medical study or trial related to this entity.
A more specific type of the condition, where applicable, for example 'Type 1 Diabetes', 'Type 2 Diabetes', or 'Gestational Diabetes' for Diabetes.
A medical test typically performed given this condition.
URL of the item.
A condition the test is used to diagnose.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.
A short description of the item.
A medical guideline related to this entity.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.
If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
The stage of the condition, if applicable.
The stage represented as a number, e.g. 3.
A medical study or trial related to this entity.
The substage, e.g. 'a' for Stage IIIa.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.
A contraindication for this therapy.
A short description of the item.
A medical guideline related to this entity.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.
The name of the item.

URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A medical study or trial related to this entity.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

A possible complication and/or side effect of this therapy. If it is known that an adverse outcome is serious (resulting in death, disability, or permanent damage; requiring hospitalization; or is otherwise life-threatening or requires immediate medical attention), tag it as a seriouseAdverseOutcome instead.
An alias for the item.
A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.
A contraindication for this therapy.
A short description of the item.
A medical guideline related to this entity.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

A factor that indicates use of this therapy for treatment and/or prevention of a condition, symptom, etc. For therapies such as drugs, indications can include both officially-approved indications as well as off-label uses. These can be distinguished by using the ApprovedIndication subtype of MedicalIndication.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.
The name of the item.
A description of the postoperative procedures, care, and/or followups for this device.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
A description of the workup, testing, and other preparations required before implanting this device.
A description of the procedure involved in setting up, using, and/or installing the device.
A goal towards an action is taken. Can be concrete or abstract.
If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.
If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

A possible serious complication and/or serious side effect of this therapy. Serious adverse outcomes include those that are life-threatening; result in death, disability, or permanent damage; require hospitalization or prolong existing hospitalization; cause congenital anomalies or birth defects; or jeopardize the patient and may require medical or surgical intervention to prevent one of the outcomes in this definition.
A medical study or trial related to this entity.
URL of the item.
Device used to perform the test.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. Relates a term (i.e. a property, class or enumeration) to one that supersedes it.
URL of the item.
